contentrichtext.text: {{Unreferenced|date=September 2009}} {{Infobox martial art form | name = Nijūshiho | other_names = Niseishi, E Sip Sa Bo | image = | imagesize = | caption = | martial_art = [[Karate]], [[Tang Soo Do]] | origin = {{flagicon|Ryūkyū Kingdom|1429}} [[Okinawa]], [[Ryukyu Kingdom]] | creator = Unknown | creation_date = Unknown }} '''Nijūshiho''' (二十四歩) (Japanese: Twenty four steps) is an advanced ''[[kata]]'' practiced in [[Shotokan]],Shitoryo and wadoryo [[karate]]. The origin of ''Nijūshiho'' is unknown, but it is presumed{{citation needed|date=May 2013}} that it originates from the Aragaki group like [[Sochin]] and others. this is shown through the similarity to [[Unsu]]. In introducing karate from [[Okinawa]] to Japan, [[Gichin Funakoshi]] changed the name of the ''kata'' from ''Niseishi'' to ''Nijūshiho''. Both names mean "24 steps." This kata is also practiced in [[Tang Soo Do]] and is called ''E Sip Sa Bo'' in Korean. Due to its difficulty, this kata is often reserved for advanced black belt level students. Like its Japanese and Okinawan counterparts ''E Sip Sa Bo'' also translates to “24 steps.” ==External links== *[http://www.prestonkarate.solarchidesigns.com/images/preston%20karate%20shotokan%20nijushiho%20kata%20diagram.jpg Nijushiho kata diagram] ==See also== *[[Bunkai]] *[[Kata]] *[[Shotokan]] {{Karate}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nijushiho}} [[Category:Shotokan]] [[Category:Karate kata]]
